If you want a view, the Stratosphere tower is better.  There are other good views of the Strip (many hotel rooms with Strip views, Voodoo Lounge, Ghostbar, Foundation Room)  I can understand how people from small towns who've never been above 5 stories in a building would be "amazed" by going up 550 feet.  How much it's worth will depend upon how much you value being 550 feet above the backside of the Strip.

I have gone on the High Roller twice now.. once during the day & the other at night.  The daytime visit: There is a locals deal $5 off per person & each adult admits a youth. Since my sister has 3 little ones, I got to tag along with her family. We printed our tickets at home & waited a short time in line (they chose the first ride time of the day). After that, you walk through.. they have a little bag check, then you head up & there's a bar, then before you get in line to board a pod, there's an option to take pictures in front of a green screen.  There were about 15 people on the pod & it was great.. not too crowded & everyone wandered to every corner to check out the views. There are screens at the top of the pod with a guy talking (didn't pay too much attention, obviously) & it displayed how many feet we were ascending periodically. When you are about to reach the top, they do a countdown which is pretty fun. The ride is approximately 30 minutes & it doesn't even feel like you're moving. Overall, daytime visit was not bad.. pictures came out decent & not too much reflection.  The night time visit: my relatives were visiting, so we decided to check out the High Roller at night because they (& I) wanted pictures of the Strip at night when it's all lit up. So, there was a total of 11 of us, which from my first visit, I assumed that they'd only fit a few more people onto the pod with us. Um, WRONG. There were about 25 of us.. give or take a person or two. So I understand that these pods can fit up to 40 people but you shouldn't do it. It totally took away from the experience. Also, people should be courteous to others.. don't stick to one part of this small space! I think the best part of the pod is the southwest corner which one couple hogged & would not move because they were in their own world taking selfies.  I'm excited that Las Vegas has the highest observation wheel at the moment. If you have 30 minutes to kill.. check it out!

My husband and I went on the HR a few weeks after it was open.  I am not aware if there is a locals discount nor did the ticket person ask if we were locals. We paid the $34.95 each. We came on a Wednesday night and went right up to the front of the line.   There was one other group in front of us. But they put all seven of us together in the same pod. They had an annoying child who kept jumping up and down. They had drinks and were buzzed, how do I know? They did not use their indoor voices. Wow.  Even at a discount it would not have changed my mind. It's just overhyped. 550ft is nice but I honestly think it would have been better if they positioned further back from the Strip. Or maybe if it was even taller. Yes I think they could have built it even taller...  Yes the sunset was pretty, yes it is a cool view of the buildings but I would say that only about the top 550ft view. Going up and going down is just meh.   Three stars.

We're locals, so we were really excited to finally experience the High Roller. The line was long so we bought our tickets at the kiosk. They cost $40 each. As we were walking in, we noticed a sign that says locals save $5. We mentioned that we just bought tickets and didn't get the $5 discount & the employee told us if we bought them at the kiosk, it was too late to get the discount. He was quite rude about it. We figured we'd deal with it after our ride & proceeded to the attraction. There's a bar there, so we bought a couple drinks & waited in line for the ride. The drinks were expensive, but we knew the drinks would be at this new tourist attraction.   The pods you sit in were really nice. We were with about 10 other people, which was fine, we didn't feel overcrowded and it was easy to move within the pod. The view was magnificent, of course. The ride is about 30 min long. If you're afraid of Ferris wheels, don't be afraid of this one. It goes so slow, you don't even feel like you're moving.  When we finished the ride, we tried to see if we could get our $5 local discount. The girl we talked to was even more rude about it than the first guy we spoke to. She actually rolled her eyes at me. My boyfriend then asked to speak to a manager. She basically refused to get the manager until we continually insisted on seeing a manager. We were then led to the manager by a different employee. The manager quickly apologized & credited $10 to my boyfriend's credit card. In addition to the $5 discount, she said locals 17 and under ride free.  However, we didn't see this special posted anywhere. I'm sure lots of families would come if their kids ride free. Why offer these discounts if they don't really advertise them?  We paid $70 for the tickets & another $25 for 2 drinks. For $95, I'd say go to Ghostbar or the Voodoo Lounge & enjoy the same view &  enjoy more than 1 cocktail!

so last review said I was to come here just once. but since my parents came I had to take them here. though still the greastest view it is not for faint of heart lol. but still enjoyable, no groupon I can find this time.

I took my family on the High Roller in July 2016, and we thought the ride offered great views, but was nothing special.  The price for an adult is $35, children under 12 are free.  There are many Groupons and living socials deals to save you a couple of dollars.  You enter a bubble, and as the giant wheel makes one complete revolution you get incredible views of the Las Vegas Strip.  The revolution takes about 30-40 minutes.  The wheel moves very slow and is very stable, if not for the changing view, you would not even know you were moving.  The only down side is that you are crammed in the pod with a lot of people you don't know.  If one of them is a drunk bung-hole, it will be a long 30 minutes.  After you get off the ride, you'll be offered to buy your green screen picture that you took prior to entering the High Roller for the special price of $50!!!  Are they serious?!?  I guess if you are in a group of people on you all share the price it's no big deal.  But if you are just a couple or a family, that is a lot for a posed picture.  If you have never been on the High Roller I would recommend doing it at least once, but only once in the evening, to get the best views.  Make sure you get a deal and don't pay full price.
I wish they could space you out more on a slow night. We were in a pod with loud and rude kids, kind of running the experience. Overall worth doing once, but not really that worth a second visit

I was expecting something a lot more exciting so yeah, it was ok.  I didn't feel like this was a "wow" for me, although my spouse thought it was cool so there ya go.  I had a Living Social deal for 2 ppl, nighttime entry and 2 drinks( worth 10.00 each) for 54.00.  If you're contemplating a visit, please check groupon or Living Social.  There is always a deal to be had.

My family and I experienced the ride last weekend while in town. It's kinda neat at night to ride if your not looking for high speed and thrills. Very scenic at the top, kinda one of those things you can check off your list that you did it. The only complaint it's a little pricy.

We went on a beautiful Wednesday night which wasn't overly crowded.. This new ride was fun,beautiful views,clean but come on over $75.00 for 2 is pricey. It is definitely not a thrill or much excitement rather than just a fun time. Never would I pay for it again.....

I bought a Living Social voucher for $25 for 30 minutes and open bar. I enjoyed myself, but definitely would NOT pay full price for this. They pack about 25 people in each pod with only one bartender. It would have been nicer if there were two bartenders. The regular pods (without alcohol) have less people in them. The pods are WAY bigger than they appear. There is not much seating inside either, so prepare to stand. Try to go at dusk or night to enjoy all the lights. We even saw the Bellagio fountains dancing from the High Roller.

I was lucky that we got to experience this free, because it was not super exciting and the price  is not what I would ever pay to do this, but we both found it enjoyable.  The video that plays was funny, but it was also a distraction from being in the moment and taking in the view.   At the time I felt like I was dragging my husband through this and since it was hot, I felt really bad about it. Luckily afterward I heard him telling others about it and he thought it was kinda a cool thing, but agreed it wouldn't be something that you would need to do more than once and that the price was too high.  It would have been worth it if the admission and bar drinks were included, at about $20 for me. So maybe after all the hype has died down, they will make it more reasonably priced?  If you are dragging around someone that is hurting, probably best to Valet the car. lol

This was something my mom was dead set on doing in Vegas, so we walked to the hotel and experienced this gigantic Ferris wheel. It isn't really much of an adventure, so I think the price is kind of a joke. The view is great, it really is, expect there are much taller buildings in the way at certain intervals.   The people who work here clearly don't care and that is upsetting when you are on vacation, and even more upsetting since this is a new attraction and these people are already not amused. The employees at any attraction are just as important as the attraction, look at Disney's philosophy, so maybe this company should put more emphasis on how they treat and train their employees.
Lots of hype; tickets were free so won't complain.  Beautiful view of strip at night but hard to take pictures of it due to reflection from glass.

We bought a groupon for 2 people. Price was about 65.00. We did one circle that took 30 minutes. Im glad we got to experience it but i wouldnt do it more than once. The views were so-so. The stratosphere has better views and more to do so i think thats the way to go.

Eh, this could be so much better. They over pack the pods and your drinks are extremely limited. In addition, they make it seem like it's a dressy event and it is so not. We were the only people dressed up.

Move over Singapore Flyer! You are no longer the tallest observation wheel in the world!   The High Roller at The Linq in Las Vegas is!  Nestled behind The Imperial Palace, er I mean, The Linq is a giant wheel of metal and glass bubbles that does one rotation inside of 30 minutes!  My gf and I were lucky that our timing was impeccable because we arrived when one of the pods was almost out of entrance range, that there was only one other couple inside it.  Unlike the other pods where there were more than 6-8 people inside!  It is almost as if we had the pod to ourselves, almost!  While the overall environment controlled cabin was pleasent, the seating could have been improved by using padded seats instead of the hard, sterile plastic that awaited our butts! Not that it mattered too, too much as you would find yourself standing most of the time in this ride marveling at the bright Vegas strip lights below!   What is definitely sorely needed is a way to disable the annoying infomercial playing on the screen inside the cabin.  The host of the informative show was tolerable the first 5 minutes, but a whole 30 minutes of badly scripted jokes and anecdotes,  one has had enough crass!   Perhaps there should be a way to switch to a radio station, or to satellite radio playing music instead?  The High Roller is best experienced during night time, or at dusk. Although, I wouldn't mind going during the day if the oppportunity came up.    The selections at the pre-boarding bar could be a little bit better, as it was quite pricy.  Like most tourist attractions, you can't bring your own food or drinks, even if it is Vegas where one could get intoxicated on the strip itself!  Happy high rolling!

We had fun! The ride takes about 30-40 minutes and the night view of Vegas is awesome.  Upon arriving we saw a huge line but then realized it was to purchase your ticket. We bought our tickets online and printed them at home and we walked right on. There is a bar to buy drinks before you get on. During the ride t.v. screens are telling you how high you are while on the ride.  It was fun but a little too expensive for my taste.

It seems like the views look way better at night. The view was cool at 4:30pm, but nothing super impressive. Also, I wouldn't suggest going on this if you're afraid of heights.   We got a deal where it was unlimited drinks while the wheel goes around for about half an hour. Luckily, it wasn't too crowded and the bartender makes the drinks pretty quickly. As skeptical as I was, it really was unlimited drinks. My friend definitely took advantage. Let's just say it didn't end up well after we got off.  Overall, it's pretty chill, unlimited drinks, check out the vegas view and just hang out. It was cool for this one time, but I probably wouldn't do this again. Well, maybe a night for a cool view.

A-OK. We got a living social deal for a ride on the High Roller and a drink up to the value of $9 for $18 each, It was a few more dollars for the night time ride, We turned up showed our ticket and went to get a drink from the bar, the whole building was pretty cool! A bit like a theme park queue at Disneyland, then it was time to board our pod, i think we got lucky as there was a huge party before us who all got in one pod together then we were next and we were in a pod with only a few others so i think its all pot luck on what time you go, The whole ride takes around 30 minutes with a pretty annoying video commentary of some annoying guy, The pods are quite large with plastic hard seating in places around the pod, but you do get a 360 degree view of Las Vegas through the big windows around the pod, Unfortunatly though the view isn't all that great, all you get to see is the back of the Hotels,the mountains in the distance  and the Airport,  and we got a better view from our hotel at the Cosmopolitan. Though it was cool to go on the tallest observation wheel in the world at a staggering 550ft!!!
Glad we went at night.   The trivia was fun. The comedian video host was.... trying. The views were AMAZING. 30 minute ride - it moves much slower than you expect it to.

I enjoyed this ride but did have an issue with the happy hour day charge versus night charge.  We purchased the tickets through a third-party vendor and had to pay $10 to upgrade to the evening.  Gratefully, the staff accommodated our request to change to the evening - I just want everybody to be aware of the small print!  Great views and Reese was a wonderful bartender!

For a panoramic view experience, they're better places in Las Vegas. First of all, to get to the high roller entrance, you will have to walk a lot. We took the monorail, seeing that it stops a few yards from the wheel, but in reality, you have to return to the strip to get to the street that leads to the high roller entrance. So I wouldn't recommend the monorail to go there.  Once you get to the entrance, there's a quick bag security check and off you go in the next line to be selected by groups of 10 to 15.  Because the experience lasts 30 minutes, I really needed to make sure I could sit. The employee was really nice and accommodating and made sure I was up front to enter and choose my seat.  The concept is really cool and he view is nice. We were lucky and got to see the Bellagio fountain show while on top of the wheel, which made the experience quite unique and fun. The first and last few minutes are not impressive as you only see the ugly close by building, but once you pass the half way point it makes it nice.  Make sure you do your research as they're many offers to do this very cheap. Enjoy the view.

We happened to get some free tickets to ride the High Roller on a recent trip to Vegas. We had a busy day and night with shows, gambling, and sightseeing, so we didn't make it to the High Roller until around 1 am. This was actually a great time to go as there were very few people in line. Our group had six people and a baby, and we wound up getting a pod with us and one other person. This was great because we were able to wander around the pod at our leisure without worrying about getting in someone else's way or photo.   The ride lasts about 30 minutes. There's some seating on the inside, but not a lot. It was fine for our small group, though we didn't sit too much anyways. It revolves at a slow pace, so you can't really feel the movement. The views are nice, though I think you get a better view from Mix Lounge at Mandalay Bay. It's a cool one-time experience. However, if I got free tickets again, I would probably give it another go.

Finally got to ride the High Roller last week and I must say it's a little overrated. I wouldn't have paid full price for it. Beautiful night view but after 15 mins I got bored and just sat down the rest of the ride. The tv and the lame music they play got annoying. As everybody else said this would be a one time try.

The new High Roller located at The Linq is the world's tallest observation wheel that provides a 360 degree view of Las Vegas and the Strip. Being a local, I decided that I would go ahead and try it out (mostly just to say that I have done it).  Just a little about the attraction... there are a total of 28 cabins that hold about 40 passengers each. It's about a 30 minute ride that takes you 550 feet above the Strip. The cost for adults is $19.95 (open till 6PM) and $34.95 (6PM till close). We decided to go later in the evening when the views would be at their best. Luckily when we arrived (11PM or so), there wasn't a wait and were able to purchase our tickets and board the cabin within 5 minutes. There is a bar that you are able to stop at before boarding if you wish to take a drink with you. If you looking to waste a bunch of money, you can also rent a private cabin for your group (approx. $1300) or even purchase a bottle service (approx. $1800). Keep in mind, this is only good for once around so it's a pretty penny for only a 30 minute ride.   All in all, it was a fun experience. We got some great pictures and the view is amazing, but I don't know if I would pay $34.95 to do it again. It's one of those, you do it once and then never again. I know since I've gone, they've started to offer packages, local discounts and discounts through Groupon, etc. I would be sure to check those out before heading straight to the box office to get tickets.   A couple tips... TIP #1: Go at night... they open at 12PM, but the views are far better if you go during the sunset or later at night. TIP #2: I mentioned it before, but check various sites for discounts! TIP #3: If you aren't walking there, there's a valet located off of Koval (of course it's complimentary!).
Groupon!!    Be sure to get the pod with the open bar after 10pm - it's the only way to do it!

Save your money, don't do it! Lol  Pros: Nice strip view up top. 21 and up slots that offer drink all you can while on the ride. Tip: buy the groupon.  Cons: Nice strip view up top. (You can just go to any strip hotel, go to the top floor and see the same thing.   21 and up slots that offer drink all you can while on the ride: go play slots, and order drink all you can. Lol  How much can you really drink in 30 mins to justify your $40 ticket? If it's $5 for the ride, I'd be more all up for it. It really isn't just worth it. t least I can say, I've done it.

The view is amazing but our visit was tainted by the horrible customer service we received at the beginning of our visit. The "manager" sat by as an employee continually condescended my family and then snapped at me when I let him know that he was rude and patronizing. Mike from the Bay Area, you have abhorrent social skills. Customer service needs to be vastly improved. Just buy your tickets in advance and don't bother with "guest services" so you do not have to deal with the attitude.

Our experience at the High Roller was not as advertised. Perhaps going during the day when the view is less spectacular helped contribute to that, but either way we felt we paid a good deal of money for a largely mediocre time.   We bought our tickets online because it shaves a few bucks off that way. We also decided to go during the day as opposed to a night ride because the difference in price was a steep $20 per person. After doing research, we chose to spend the extra money for a happy hour pod which provides access to an open bar throughout the duration of the 30 minute ride and the ticket price includes your drinks.  There are no set times on the tickets since the ride constantly rotates (even when you board, but don't worry it moves slowly). We didn't realize there is only one happy hour pod on the entire wheel, so we had to wait in line and let the others roll by until it was at ground level for us to get on.   Being the first HH ride of the day, we also had to wait for them to wheel the bar in. The line kept growing along with my anxiety from seeing the size of the pods. While spacious, we watched general admission ticket buyers (who paid less) going ahead of us (some getting a pod all to themselves) while we got to be packed in like sardines. Have I mentioned I'm both claustrophobic and terrified of heights? Talk about self-inflicted wounds.   I'm not sure why I assumed there would be a limit of 15 people or so as to not overcrowd the pods, but I was wrong. They put 25 of us in there which doesn't sound bad, until the doors close and you are having to squeeze through people to walk around and see the different views.   We also didn't realize that "happy hour" actually meant sales pitch hour. We now know how much it costs to rent the pods out for corporate events, holidays, and weddings. Because of an unfortunate incident of a man drinking 25 beers in one ride and then peeing in the bartenders sink, you are also not allowed to hold more than one drink at a time. As in you can't order one for your spouse on the other side of the pod and pass it to them, everyone has to come to the bar themselves and only touch their own drinks.  While I understand the reasoning behind it, it made serving everyone take longer and we were only able to get two small drinks each the entire time. Worth the price? We didn't think so.   If you still want to go however, then this is what I suggest:  1) Go at night.  2) Don't pay extra for a HH pod. The ride is short, go to the bar afterwards.  3) Snag a standing spot on the side you enter from as that's where the best view is.  4) Buy your tickets online for a better price.

We didn't ride this ride for a couple of reasons. It was too expensive, just about $20.  If you look for those hotel coupon books, they will give you a discount of $3-$4 per person.  We rode the London Eye in London and this looked just like it so we decided to skip it altho' we did get under it to see what it looked like.  They have electronic kiosks for you to purchase your tickets.  Not sure if the Las Vegas area is as nice to look at compared to London but $20/per person was too much in my opinion for a short ride.

Not a wonderful experience, but not a terrible one either. Personally, a bit mediocre, nothing breathtaking or particularly memorable -- we saw a bunch of the hotels and they were all lit up. Yet it was not as bright and flashy as I had envisioned in my head. That could be my fault, hyping it up from what others have said. It was a lot brighter and more energetic on the ground than in the air.   Overall, it was quiet in our little pod cause it was around Christmas/a weeknight around 11PM. It was only my husband and I, plus a dad and his three daughters. The music playing was lively and energetic, maybe a way to inject more fun in the experience. The young girls were dancing around and it was cute. Actually found that a bit more entertaining than the view.   I think a lot of the 5 star reviews involve the packages that come with unlimited booze. Because, anything is super fun while drunk. However, my husband and I aren't drinkers so opted for just the regular ticket.   Pricey for what the experience really is: 30 minutes long, some songs blasting. Regular night time ticket --no booze -- $37. I got discounted vouchers and paid $29 per ticket instead and I still kind of think it was a rip- off. Also the ascent was super slow, and I thought it would be a bit faster. The slow ascent was good though, because it seemed very gradual and any faster might make some people nervous or nauseous.   The staff is also very friendly from every interaction I had -- before entering the box for the ticket line, the guy manning the entrance was helpful in directing me where to go. I had never been here and had a voucher and was unsure where to go. The girl assisting us with tickets was nice. Bag check girl was sweet, commenting on how she liked my bag, saying you're welcome as we thanked them.   Once you go upstairs, there's a bar and bathrooms. I'm guessing you could buy some alcoholic beverages and take it with you? Then we pass through another area where they make us take pictures in front of a green screen, no doubt to try to sell us when we leave. It was actually very cute in terms of the background shot, but we didn't like how we looked and opted not to get it. Finally, we get to the last line area, but quickly run into the open pod as it's moving, and then we made our way up! No lines anywhere, but this was obviously not peak season in Las Vegas. At other times of the year, especially Spring/Summer, I can foresee the lines being long.   I'm not sure how many people they permit inside one pod, but hopefully they do not over pack everyone inside and have a strict limit. It would be hard to get a good view, and it might feel a bit claustrophobic. I also wonder if the pods differ in size. The non-open bar ones are small, and have less people inside. The open bar pods must accommodate a bar/staff, and a lot more people.   While mostly everyone stands, there are some seats that you can sit down if you need a little rest.   Also, the gift shop was super cute and fun to look through. I normally never buy stuff in gift shops because the mark-ups are insane, but I saw an adorable "Sad Panda" shirt (panda looking bummed that their mug of (presumably) beer had tipped and spilled on the ground) and could not resist the purchase. Again, those cashiers were friendly and joking around with customers behind me. For working in a quiet store at midnight, that's some good energy and customer service.

It's good to try once in your life, but I can't see myself doing this again. It's a good thing we had a BOGO coupon.  Pods are larger than they appear, so don't worry about overcrowding.  You can easily get these high views by going to the stratosphere or any hotel that is higher than 40 stories high.  Night views are better than day time views.

For $35 this was just ok. I tried to find some good deals on Living Social and Groupon  but I couldn't. The ride is only 30 minutes long but anything more than 30 minutes would've been too long.   I mainly came up here to take pictures. However, that was difficult because the windows are glass with no way to open them and that the glass was dirty. I turned off my camera flash but that only helped a little bit.

Do whatever you can to get a discount. Military, local, or whatever. Just make sure to ask them about discounts. Now on a serious note. Should or should you not get the open bar car or not. If you want to knock a few back, pre-game, get drunk, etc... Then you need to get the drinking car. The bartenders are really fast and trust me you can do some serious damage during the ride. The cart without the drinks is cool too. Tip... Make sure you have a good place to stand near the strip before you get to the top. Everyone will try to take pics on that side and if you wait too long, you will miss out. The view is only good for 30% of the ride.   Pros - open bar for a good price, something different, location. Parking  Cons - Price without discount, amount of folks in a car.

On Wednesday, July 8th at 10:50pm, I boarded the High Roller.  Luckily our group found a Groupon for One happy half hour late night package with open bar for two: valid 7pm to 1am ($75). Plus, we had 20% off on top of the Groupon price, so it ended up being $30 per person. Make sure to check in and select a time before you plan on actually going on the High Roller. We dropped by, went and had dinner and then came back.  I heard someone say they offer top shelf liquor for the open bar, but that's not true. It's the standard liquor you would expect with Jack Daniels being the whiskey. I'm a dark drinker, so I stuck to Jack and Coke. I heard someone try to order a red bull vodka, but unfortunately, they don't have any energy drinks.  Since I couldn't drink much during this open bar, I was excited that they offered Fiji water. With the one cocktail I consumed, I'm pretty sure I drank enough Fiji water to make up for the rest of the cocktails I didn't consume.  Now onto the reason for this, the Ferris Wheel! I love ferris wheels since I love views. But I realize I love them when it's quiet and serene. I've been on a number of them, but it's always been with 1-3 other people. Being in a pod with loud drinkers took a little away from that. At night, the lights of Vegas are great, but it didn't feel like we were at the top for very long. And you can't see anything on the desert side since it's just darkness.  I'm glad I finally tried the ferris wheel with friends that wanted to go as this might have been something I'd drag the roommate on. Great to try once, but I wouldn't do it again.

The view was awesome. The ride is really slow so it does allow you to view the city at different levels. My issue was the drink prices and the way it was explained or attempted to be explained to me. I paid $18 for a frozen daqauri with an extra shot of tequila. I felt nothing. Way too high for a drink. But the ride was pretty nice. You go in a small group so don't expect to go alone unless there is no one else around.

I have been on the High Roller twice now and I have to say it is much more enjoyable with drinks ;-) but if you're not a drinker it's worth the views.   Let me start by saying that this is a VERY SAFE ride and if you're afraid of heights or get vertigo this might actually be a good viewing point where you will not feel overwhelmed. I brought a friend who is afraid of heights and she said she enjoyed it. The ride moves very slow so you don't really feel like you're on a "ride" per se. It's similar to an elevator going up (you can barely feel it).  The views are great and it takes about 30 minutes roundtrip. I recommend going up at night as night views are always nicer (in my opinion). The pods are fairly large and fit quite a few people. I have never been in a pod that was crowded so I found that seating was plenty.   It's a great ride if you want a unique view of the strip and the entire las vegas valley. I will say it's not the best spot to go if you want to get a great overhead view of the Bellagio fountains (go to the Paris Eiffel Tower Experience for that (see my review)).   I honestly couldn't say much about pricing because I always get to go up for free (That's right, I'm connected like that ;-) ) but I would say it's consistent with other attractions on the strip offering up similar views. Plus, there's alcohol!   **As long as it's not heavy rainstorm outside, it's still possible to do this ride, however, the view might not be so great. I live in Las Vegas and I've seen the High Roller operate in the rain.

This is an awesome experience especially with the open bar package. It is a 30 minute ride and all you can drink. We have been on it twice. The first time it was only thee couples on it and was a great experience. The second time, it would have been a small group but the group before us had a girl puking all over so we had to wait for the next one. By that time, the group grew to over 20 people on the ride. It was crowded and you could not see much since all the spaces on the ride was packed. I was real annoyed with that.

I had to go on the High Roller for business a few weeks ago. Luckily I live in Las Vegas so it only cost me $20. I think like every other Las Vegas corporate gouging this attraction to is up there. Not sure of the non-resident fee but it ain't cheap.  I understand that they're not doing well, which comes as no great surprise.. People just can't afford to shell out that kind of money to see basically the same view they could see from the top of their hotel.

I went here on the 16th and it was pretty cool. You go inside this giant ball and it has a couple benches. It fits quite a few people. The tickets we got were "all you can drink" and there's a bartender and he makes you what you want...it's not a full bar so don't expect too much. I suggest asking him if he has any special drinks he makes. The bartender that we had made us some "bartender special" drinks and they were really good. Bring cash to tip. The ride lasts about a half hour and when you enter the ride, try to stay by the side that you entered...then you can see the strip! The other side doesn't have too much on it. It's cool to do once but I probably wouldn't do it again. Personally, I think it needed to be in a better location. Also, the bartender cut my husband off and he wasn't even drunk lol. They're small cups and a lot of ice. "All-you-can-drink" my ass. And no, he wasn't drunk at any point when we got off the ride either so I don't know why he was cut off. My uncle had more drinks than my husband and didn't get cut off.

My boyfriend and I went on the High Roller this past Thursday evening around 10pm. We used a groupon and were able to redeem it easily at guest services. There wasn't a wait at all when we went and we actually had an observation pod to ourselves. The pod next to us was the happy hour pod and it was PACKED with people - they looked like they could barely move. The groupon price is $69 which is basically the price of two night tickets - it's only a deal if you get the happy hour all-you-can-drink option ($109 for two), but beware that you might be packed in like sardines.   There are two benches inside to sit down and you get a 360 degree view through the observation pod windows. It was pretty cool to see the strip all lit up from 550 feet up (if you get lucky you can see the bellagio water fountain show) and there's music playing but the ride is incredibly slow. The entire experience is 30-45 minutes and once you get to the top, coming down is pretty uneventful. There are some screens with a really corny narrator who gives you information about the ride - I wish there was an option to turn him off. We ended up going again on Saturday with my cousins who had free passes. I honestly wouldn't go again unless I was going for free but it's definitely something to experience.

Anxious to see Vegas from many views and perspectives, our party of four jumped at the libation included 550' observation ferris wheel at a price of $60 person -with unlimited opportunities. The ride is 30 minutes in duration and the quantity of guests per cab can go anywhere between; half empty, full and a bit of a challenge to move around. A mood was set when the doors closed and the tender stated; "the way this works is you help me and I help you". He started with a too sweet concoction for all and then took limited requests of one's favorite drinks. My analysis... should be closer to $45 ($47 if you purchase on-line), and seen as a one trick pony.

This was a fun one time venture. Open bar but weak drinks and a less than accommodating bartender. The service at the Line - concierge however was so great! They helped me with my groupon and app...they gave me water and we're sweet to charge my phone!! We reserved the sunset time and the view is great..A must do for vegas newbies

For someone who has sky dived and still fear heights (they say it's best to conquer your fears by facing it... well, it didn't work for me) this was an exciting and yet scary experience for me. The ride is smooth but as it gets higher and higher so did my blood pressure and sweaty palms. Seemed like everyone else in our cabin was just fine - my family plus another family. Kids and adults were standing on the edge some even leaning against the rail which really made me nervous! The structure and engineer work looks impressive until I noticed there were two bolts missing attaching our cabin to the wheel (I'm sure it was by design but couldn't they have filled those holes?). Plus side -- views were great all around and my kids under 13 rode for free and we got $5 discounts off adult tickets. My recommendation for those who fear heights but still want to go on it, have a drink before going up. Oh and the on boarding off boarding part was interesting -- you walk up to the moving cabin with no safety railings in place (not really) just workers there to guide you -- think if you misstepped and fell over the edge oh man! Luckily there's a safety net in place, however you don't see it until you're in the cabin so you have to kind of take a leap of faith.

$35 for 30 min ride, I was expecting a bit more. After viewing their website, suggesting that you can actually have a " party" in these carts, I was expecting to have the cart to our own party. & also a much bigger cart. However, we were crowded with two other parties. Which I thought was unnecessary because 1) our party was a large group of people 2) it was late at night, there was not much people, the cart behind us was EMPTY  it ended up that it wasn't too much of a party atmosphere because the cart was not that huge, there was limited sitting area. Whatever playing on the tv also seems like for kids instead of adults. Also the other group was a group of guys and I guess got really high cuz they saw our huge group of girls. The WHOLE time was trying to talk to us. ehhh....   Also the High Roller actually never stops, so running in and out of the cart freaked me out, since I was with my friends bachelorette, and we were all wearing high heels.   Although the view is great, but I wouldn't pay $35 for this.

This review is pretty easy:  Cost $35 for the view you are paying for the view and nothing else. More or less pictures of the view. Oh and hopefully you get in the same pod with some cool people if not that can make or break your round a bout. So it is up to you how much is the view of Vegas worth to you. Night is always better to me because the day time all you see is desert.
It was fun~we got the bar 1... be warned.. they dont have red wine.. which was a huge disappointment.. but great views at night!!

A friend and I managed to get a 2 for 1 voucher after joining the Total Rewards program. Really recommend finding promos, online deals, etc. when visiting to save as much as you can and they offer some good deals if you look for them! Since day admission is only $25, we saved a bunch by splitting the cost. Apparently the High Roller is larger than the London Eye, but having ridden both I really couldn't tell the difference. It may be bigger, but there's a lot more to see when you're on top of the London Eye as opposed to just looking over the Strip. The ride took about 30 minutes total and my group and I mostly had the whole pod to ourselves which was nice. They do offer an open bar pod for an additional $10, but since I'm not really a big drinker I doubt I would've taken advantage of that in 30 minutes. From what I witnessed they try to squeeze in as many people that can fit in the bar pods. I was perfectly happy in my quiet pod, lot of space to walk around and take in the views and snap some pictures.

The view is great. The pictures I took were amazing. My selfie stick captured even larger scenic views. The ride last 30 minutes and it gives you a 5 second count down before you hit the peak of height. Not all pods have bars. If you decided to add this option its $10 more and unlimited. I did not purchase the bar options because you are allowed to bring your own drinks as long as not in glass containers. And honestly I was so busy taking pictures, talking, and making memories, I didn't even finish the drink I brought in with me.  *Prices* Before7 pm $26.95 After 7 pm $36.96  $10 added to each for open bar 7 pm and earlier. $15 added after 7 pm.  Once up the escalator, you meet with photographers ready to take your picture which will be available for purchase after. Then walk into a small area with a few pictures on the wall with dates of construction of the wheel and its progress. Check it out, most people by pass it. It's ways good to know some history.   The lines seem longer at night. Sure there is lots of lights, but you don't get to see the city's architecture and layout in such detail. I purchased the before 7pm ticket and rode around 6 pm. This was a great time to see the sights. When purchasing tickets at the kiosk you can not use coupons. Head inside to purchase tickets. I found a $5 off each ticket in my hotel room booklet! Whoo-hoo! Women dressed in lime green will be on the Linq Promenade handing out $2 off coupons. They can not be combined but it's still a savings of you can't get your hands on the $5 off ones. Once off the wheel you are ushered into a gift shop with pictures available for purchase. Omg there some pricy pictures. Lol this gift shop sells full size family size bags of chips! Unnecessary information but funny.  This observation wheel is the largest in the world. It's definitely a must do once. Also make sure you get a coupon. No reason to pay full price. You can earn total reward points by making this purchase but they will not be awarded to you on site. Ask for your receipt and head to your total rewards booth where points will be given then.

We went mid afternoon and got a pod to ourselves - it's a great experience and is higher than any other observation wheel, so you do get a good view.  The commentary is very cheesy but the little ones will love it.  Having done the London Eye several times, I didn't really feel wowed but if you have never done a wheel before it's defiantly worth the trip. Younger kids are free too, so it's good value at $54 for two adults. (Compare that to the London Eye and it's a bargain!!)  $5 open bar is a must try, as well.

Must Read before you go on - make sure you use the restroom before you get on especially if you are drinking.. its about a 30 min ride and you are not getting off. If you are afraid of heights, think twice before you go. You are enclosed so its not like a regular fair ferris wheel that is out in the open with air to help ease your stomach.   Two types of tickets - Full Admission and General   Full Admission (pricey $38 at night) - you get a bar in the center of the pods... fits about 40 people standing. Fun for groups. Even can be a great spot to propose if everyone in there is your friends and family.  General Admission ($10) - no bar open with a little space to sit but still no restroom.  I would have not gone on if I had to pay for the ticket, but since I won the tickets gambling my group decided to try it out. I will not go back on it as I didn't care for it as much. The city lights were beautiful at night but to be enclosed for that long especially when you are drinking was not that great. Also we had a few people that were afraid of heights and ended up feeling sick when they got off... If you must go up bring something salty to eat just in case someone gets queezy..its about 300 ft up the ground.

If you're going to ride the High Roller check Groupon for a deal first. Paying full price (depending on what time you're going and which pod) is just silly. It's 30mins and it goes by pretty fast. I would say it's one of those things you'll ride once and never again. I was in the bar pod, which is all you can drink but you can only have one drink at a time. We made sure to get our moneys worth while in there so we were drinking fast. It was cool to experience it and see the valley like that but again a one time deal for me.

This is a very nice attraction that is definitely worth going on at least once in your life....but you don't ever need to go on it again after that.  First off, it's pricey.  Even for locals.  That right there deters me from wanting to go on it again.  It's not the most comfortable when you're in the pod.  I only had about 20 other people in the pod with me, which is about half of what it CAN hold, yet it was still difficult to move around, and I just wanted to yell, "MOVE!  You've been hogging the best spot for the whole ride!  Let someone else get a chance!" to some people.  Also, there is a super annoying guy in the video that plays the entire time you're on the ride.  And it's true: 30 minutes is a long time when you're going a foot a second.  Once you get to the top and see the amazing view, then you're bored out of your mind for the second half as it comes down.  Again, it is worth going on at least once to experience it and see the cool sights, but that's about it.  P.S. They need to invest in some good photo editing equipment.  In the picture my brother and I took, we both had glaring red eyes and looked like Terminators!

TIP: Don't wear high heels here. The High Roller never stops so you're gonna have to jump in and out. If you're not ok with possibly spraining your ankle then wear flats.  The Yelpers before me have already mentioned all the pros - nice view, clean and air-conditioned cabins, and little to no line. BUT we ran into trouble while trying to redeem the Living Social deal we had purchased for a $35 nighttime ticket + free drink. We waited in line at the Guest Services window and the girl told us we had to redeem it at the Linq concierge, a couple doors down. To make a long story short, we found out later that we could've redeemed it at the window we originally were at OR in the main ticket office. I really have no idea why that girl had us go down to the Linq concierge. A regular price ticket is $35 so I don't think all the hassle was worth it for a 30 minute ride.

My friend treat me here and I treat her back with drinks. It was nice, just to experience it even just once. I guess it's a nice place to catch up with friends who are new to the place so they can see around too.

enjoyed the ride and the view from the top.  i think it is worth it - you can get some really cool pictures of vegas from varying angles.  i'm sure right at dusk or late evening would have beautiful views (we went mid-afternoon on a clear day so we could see pretty far out).  the only thing i would say is that it is so new, the price or deals will start popping up... if each person was ~$15-20, it would definitely be right on target - as it stands its probably $10-15 over-priced.  wait a bit and i'm sure there will be deals to be had!

Great experience! Beautiful views of Vegas! The only downfall is that we did the happy hour ride and got Francis as a bartender who was extremely rude and constantly asked for tips. We tipped him over $20 and he made himself more drinks than he made us. Great experience, horrible bartender!
Paid extra for the happy half hour. It would not have been so bad but they packed it do you we're practically elbow to elbow.

Teenage daughter loved it.  No line at all on a Thurs night around 9:45pm.  The ride is about 30-40 minutes.  We got a discount online, on Cesear Hotel's website.  Ticket was  $32.  Pricing is a little crazy but it is one of the tallest ferry wheel rides.  Didn't know you can bring drinks on it!  I'm scared of heights but that will definitely take the edge off. Next time!

Review for Happy Half Hour Day experience: our group decided to take part in the happy half hour at the Groupon rate which was reasonable and gave us no trouble when we got there.  There was no big line to get into the attraction except when you get outside to actually get on the High Roller, even then the line moved quickly. It's actually only when you are about to get on you notice that the wheel doesn't stop rotation and you literally have to hop on, which is pretty cool and questionable since we were hopping on to drink!  Now to the nitty gritty, I gave a three because the person I saw the most, Phadrah (however you spell it) the Bartender heavily negatively impacted my experience. I understand she has a job to do but from the beginning I could see she wasn't about being a Bartender just wasting my time. Note this cab can hold up to 40 people so it should be imperative to provide SPEEDY AND FRIENDLY service. If I could call her out her name I would because I felt she put Bartenders to shame and at the same time tried to prevent me from getting the most out of the deal. I've worked in customer service and been a patron to many a bar and not once still I feel she even cared if I was having a good time much less if I felt thirsty. I was basically on the verge of making my own drinks, but stuck to mainly beer so that I wouldn't have to heavily rely on her service. And when we got towards the end she didn't even have the courtesy to do a last call, she simply started talking about how much it was to privately rent it out (really, do we look interested!) and to focus on a video of how the High Roller was built, that she never even put on.... Then to top if off she was giving side eyes before we left with the biggest attitude when a few of us tried to get our last drink before we left (Keep your feelings at home! Don't bring them to work!)   Keep in mind, the views were great and probably would've been better at night but given that I actually drink during Happy Hours I would be a little concerned for my safety during the night ride since you have to jump off at the end. But Overall, a good experience and meeting new intoxicated people is hilarious as well !!!!

I waited for the Groupon before I went on this, 'cause it's pricy. $69 for admission for 2 with either flex pass (go day/night whenever you like) or Happy Half Hour (open bar for the duration of your trip, weekdays only). It also comes with a 20% off food at Brooklyn Bowl, a free polaroid at the Polaroid store, and 15% off any item in the gift shop.  First thing I noticed: everyone here hates their job. The bag checkers could not have cared less about us. I showed my Groupon voucher and the girls says, "Sorry, I need to see the ticket." I was like...okay, isn't this a ticket? And she sighs and huffs and puffs and says, "NO, a REAL ticket. Go to the concierge." Cryptic and rude! But we went to concierge next to the Brooklyn Bowl and got real tickets printed out and were finally allowed in.  It's a long, long windy path up to the actual High Roller. There's a set of green screens against a wall and some "photographers" who basically push you up against the screen, click two pictures, and hand you a ticket without even looking at you. I was really shocked! I gladly would have payed for my picture if it hadn't been so hurried and awful. This is a MONDAY NIGHT, mind you, with NO LINE. They aren't busy, and they just don't care. Terrible customer service.  Finally get there to the loading deck. From my understanding, there are bars in each compartment with bartenders and all. Turns out there's just a small rolling beverage cart they throw in there with a bartender and squeeze a rather large amount of people in one car. Not a lot of seating, which was uncomfortable. Bartender was very friendly.  There's video screens up top of the car that are supposed to give an "interactive experience". They don't. They just let you know what elevation you're at and give a small HOORAY! when you reach the pinnacle. The view is pretty, but not worth what we spent. I was ultimately disappointed with the whole experience. Better customer service, please!

Admittedly there are great views up near the top.  We were in a pod with about 12 total so there was lots of room to move around but there were usually people standing against the windows where we wanted to take pictures so we had to wait till they were done to get a photo ourselves.  Tip: stand on the side facing the strip when you get in, which is right when you get in the doors.  And as others said it is not a scary ride at all.  The biggest issue was the price. We went up at night and it was $36.95? per adult. pricey for a half hour ferris wheel ride.  Don't think I'd do this again.
